questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with weakness of shoulder movements. Investigations revealed quadrangular space syndrome. Which of the following nerve is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
The axillary nerve is likely to be affected as it is one of the contents of the quadrangular space.

Quadrangular space (Foramen of Velpeau) is a passageway for the nerves and vessels between the axilla anteriorly and the scapular region posteriorly.

Quadrangular space syndrome: The condition is caused by hypertrophy or fibrosis of the quadrangular space muscles which impinge on the axillary nerve. The patient presents with weakness of the shoulder movements.

The image below shows spaces around the shoulder joint. (QS: Quadrangular space, TS: Superior triangular space, TI: Inferior triangular space).

An easy way to remember these spaces is to represent your 4 fingers as structures around the 3 spaces as shown below.

Related Pearl: Spaces around shoulder joint

Spaces around shoulder joint 

(1) Quadrangular space (of velpeau)

Boundaries

  • Superiorly: Teres minor
  • Inferiorly: Teres major
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally: Surgical neck of humerus

Contents

  • Axillary nerve
  • Posterior circumflex humeral vessels

(2) Upper triangular space

Boundaries

  • Superiorly: Teres minor(posteriorly), subscapularis(anteriorly)
  • Inferiorly: Teres major
  • Laterally: long head of triceps

Contents

  • Circumflex scapular vessels

(3) Lower triangular space

Boundaries

  • Superiorly: Teres major(posteriorly), Subscapularis (anteriorly)
  • Medially: Long head of triceps
  • Laterally : humerus

Contents

  • Radial nerve
  • Profunda Brachii vessels

questions.text: An elderly man, with congestive cardiac failure, complains of shortness of breath when lying down. What is the mechanism behind this symptom?

choices.text: Reservoir function of veins in lower limbs.

questions.solution:
The given scenario describes orthopnea in congestive heart failure. It is due to reservoir function of pulmonary veins.

Orthopnea is dyspnea occurring in the recumbent position.

It results from redistribution of fluid from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities (increased venous return) into the heart during recumbency. This increased venous return is not put out by the left ventricle and hence pools in the pulmonary veins that acts as capacitance vessels (reservoir function) adding to the already congested pulmonary vasculature resulting in breathing difficulty.

questions.text: A 45-year old man who was a chronic alcoholic presented with confusion, ataxia, and diplopia. What is the treatment protocol?

choices.text: Vitamin B1 injection followed by glucose infusion

questions.solution:
The above clinical history is suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.

The current standard of treatment for patients with symptoms of Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give thiamine 100 mg intravenously before administering glucose-containing IV fluids.

Thiamine deficiency leads to the following:

    1. Wernicke’s encephalopathy: It is more commonly seen in alcoholics with chronic thiamine deficiency. It is characterized by :

  • Global confusion
  • Truncal ataxia
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Horizontal nystagmus 

    2. Korsakoff psychosis: symptoms in addition to those of Wernicke's encephalopathy include:

  • Memory loss
  • Confabulation

    3. Beriberi: It can present with sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, and muscle weakness (dry beriberi) or tachycardia, cardiomegaly, high-output cardiac failure (wet beriberi).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a painless palpable lump in her left breast. She had sustained a traumatic blow to her left breast 1 month back. Mammography showed a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The typical history of a breast lump following trauma and mammography findings of a radiolucent cystic lesion with rimmed calcification suggests a diagnosis of fat necrosis.

About half the affected women with fat necrosis of the breast have a history of breast trauma or previous surgery. It can present as a painless palpable mass, skin thickening or retraction, or mammographic densities or calcifications.

Histologically, necrotic adipose tissue with foamy macrophages, multinucleated giant cells, and chronic inflammatory cells are seen often with hemosiderin deposits, fibrosis, and calcification.

The following image shows an area of fat necrosis within breast tissue.

Note: Calcifications are seen on mammography in the following conditions -

  • Apo­crine cysts
  • Hyalinized fibroadenomas
  • Sclerosing adenosis
  • Duct ectasia 
  • Breast carcinoma- shows irregular densities and small, numerous, clustered calcification (microcalcifications).

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Microscopic agglutination test is used for diagnosis of Leptospirosis.

History of fever with liver(icterus) and kidney(hematuria) involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

questions.text: A patient complains of muscle weakness. It was reversed on the administration of neostigmine because _________

choices.text: It blocks the action of acetylcholine
It interferes with the action of choline transferase
It interferes with the action of choline acetyl transferase
It interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase

questions.solution:
Muscle weakness is improved by neostigmine as it interferes with the action of acetylcholine esterase.

Inhibition of acetylcholine esterase increases the acetylcholine levels in the synapse that can act on receptors over the large surface area and for more periods reducing the weakness.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of the appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

questions.text: Given below is a histological section of a biopsy taken from a farmer who presented with a vascular polypoidal mass protruding from his left nostril. What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histology (showing sporangia) is suggestive of rhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi.

Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.

questions.text: A patient with ptosis presented with retraction of the ptotic eyelid on chewing.  What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with ptosis presented with retraction of the ptotic eyelid on chewing. The diagnosis is Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.

  • About 5% of all cases of congenital ptosis are associated with the Marcus–Gunn jaw-winking phenomenon.
  • The vast majority are unilateral.
  • Etiology: a branch of the mandibular division of the fifth cranial nerve is misdirected to the levator muscle.
  • Signs
    • Retraction of the ptotic lid in conjunction with stimulation of the ipsilateral pterygoid muscles by chewing, sucking, opening the mouth, or contralateral jaw movement.
    • Less common stimuli to winking include jaw protrusion, smiling, swallowing, and clenching of teeth.
    • Jaw-winking does not improve with age although patients may learn to mask it.

Image: The woman cannot control her eyelids while drinking

questions.text: An​ 8-year-old child had an unprovoked dog bite. Which of the following measures should be taken?

choices.text: Withhold the vaccine and observe the dog for 10 days
Kill the dog and send brain for biopsy

questions.solution:
It is appropriate to give post-exposure prophylaxis immediately to reduce the chances of getting rabies by administering cell culture derived vaccine.

Zero by 30 : is the Global strategic plan to end human death from dog mediated rabies by 2030.

Category 1-Touching , feeding, licks on intact skin

Category 2-Minor scratches, abrasions without bleeding

Category 3- Single or multiple transdermal bites/scratches, contamination of mucous membrane with saliva, contact with blood

  CAT 1 CAT 2 CAT3 
NON IMMUNISED Wound washing

Wound washing

+

PEP

Wound washing
+

PEP
+

RIG

PREVIOUSLY IMMUNISED(Including PrEP, with proper documentation)

 

 Wound washing

Wound washing+ Vaccine

If vaccinated

<3 months -only wound management

>3months- Booster dose on 0 and 3 , IM/ID

Wound washing+ Vaccine

If vaccinated

<3 months -only wound management

>3months- Booster dose on 0 and 3 , IM/ID

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

 

1.PrEP-Pre exposure prophylaxis-3 doses 0,7 ,21/28 (IM/ID)

  • Site- adults- deltoid,<1 year old- anterolateral thigh
  • Gluteal area should not be used due to lower antibody titres

 

2.PEP-Post exposure prophylaxis 

  • IM-5 doses(1-1-1-1-1) on 0,3,7,14,28(Essen Regimen)
  • ID-4 doses (2-2-2-2) on 0,3,7,28 (Updated Thai Cross Regimen)

 

3.RIG- Rabies Immunoglobulin

  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization :Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is assessing an outbreak of acute diarrhoeal disease in a region. He wants to predict the virulence of the causative agent. Which of the following parameters will he use for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Case fatality rate is used in this scenario as it is the most useful parameter to predict the virulence of an acute illness. It represents the killing power of disease.

Note:

Case fatality rate is an incidence proportion and not a true rate as no time interval is used for its calculation.

 

Related Pearl: Case Fatality Rate

  • Case fatality rate =  (Total number of deaths due to a particular disease)/(Total number of cases due to the same disease)x 100
  • It is a good indicator of severity or killing power of a disease.
  • It is used mostly in acute and infectious diseases.
  • No time interval is used.
  • Case fatality rate is closely related to virulence.
  • Limitation of CFR is that its usefulness for chronic diseases is limited because the period from onset to death is variable.
  • It is expressed in percentage.
  • CFR is an incidence proportion and not a true rate.
  • CFR may vary for the same disease in different epidemics.

  • Case fatality of a few diseases:

    • Rabies - 100% especially after symptoms manifest
    • Ebola - 25 to 90%, average - 50% 
    • Yellow fever - 15 to 50%
    • Chicken pox - 0.001%
  • Diseases with a high case fatality rate: Tetanus, Rabies, Botulism, Ebola.
  • Diseases with a low case fatality rate: Leprosy, Trachoma, Lymphatic filariasis.

questions.text: You are a field doctor at the site of an earthquake. You assist in rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of the likelihood of their survival and need for intervention. What is this process called?
questions.solution:
The process of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention is called triage. It is carried out at the site of disaster.

Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A 50-year-old man was diagnosed with STEMI. He was admitted and given thrombolytic therapy. The next day he complained of palpitations and an ECG was taken. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows narrow QRS complex, irregular RR intervals, and absent P waves which are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. Among the given options, amiodarone can be administered in patients having atrial fibrillation with coronary or structural heart disease.

Drugs for rhythm control in atrial fibrillation:

In patients without structural heart disease, class I agents are used. Class I agents act by blocking the Na+ channels leading to slower depolarization:

  • Flecainide 
  • Propafenone
  • Disopyramide

In patients with coronary or structural heart disease, class III agents are used. Class III agents act by blocking the K+ channels leading to slower repolarization causing increased refractory period:

  • Amiodarone
  • Dofetilide
  • Sotalol
  • Ibutilide

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presented with steatorrhea and chronic diarrhea. An evaluation revealed delayed intellectual development and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. Ophthalmological examination showed the following. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image showing retinitis pigmentosa and presence of acanthocytes along with the given clinical features is suggestive of abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea and diarrhea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text: A patient is known to have mitral stenosis had an acute onset of weakness of the left arm which recovered completely in 10 days. The most likely diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
This patient with mitral stenosis and acute onset weakness of the left arm is most likely to have had an ischemic stroke. Mitral stenosis is known to cause atrial fibrillation and is a common cause of cardioembolic stroke.

Transient ischemic attack(TIA) is a temporary, focal neurological deficit of sudden onset (stroke-like symptoms) owing to focal ischemia of the brain, retina or cochlea. It lasts for less than 24 hours. Most TIAs last for less than 1 hour to a few minutes. There is a high risk of developing an ischemic stroke after a TIA, especially for the first 3 months following a TIA.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical symptoms are not observed in secondary adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Pigmentation is not observed in secondary adrenal insufficiency.

In secondary adrenal insufficiency, the skin is characterized by an alabaster-like paleness due to the lack of ACTH secretion.

questions.text: Four weeks after a head injury, a 70-year-old patient developed altered sensorium and presented with headache and  vomiting. Fundus examination showed papilledema. The probable diagnosis is ____.
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the above scenario is chronic subdural hematoma (SDH).

Chronic SDH is a collection of blood breakdown products that are at least 2 to 3 weeks old. 

It may arise from minor head injury. Alcoholics, the elderly, and patients on anticoagulation are at higher risk.

 

Imaging reveals diffuse hypodensity overlying the brain surface.

A chronic SDH >1 cm or any symptomatic SDH should be surgically drained.

Nomenclature

Time

Acute  SDH

<3 days

Subacute SDH

4–21 days

Chronic SDH

> 21 days

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has recently undergone exploratory laparotomy for acute abdomen. On 5th postoperative day, he is febrile. The sutured site is erythematous and on the removal of 2 skin sutures, there is a leakage of intestinal contents through the wound.  An electrolyte panel done on him showed hyponatremia, hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of an enterocutaneous fistula. From the electrolyte panel showing hyponatremia, hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis, a diagnosis of duodenal fistula can be made. 

Enterocutaneous fistulas are classified according to their location and volume of daily output.

  • Proximal fistulas are associated with the higher output, greater fluid and electrolyte loss, and greater loss of digestive capacity.
  • Distal fistulas tend to have lower output, making them easier to manage and more likely to close spontaneously.

questions.text: A young man presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain and 3 episodes of vomiting in the past 9 hours. He says that the pain radiates to the back and is partially relieved by bending forwards. The abdominal radiograph of the patient is given below. What is the sign that is seen in the radiograph?
questions.solution:
The given erect abdominal x-ray shows the colon cut-off sign, which is seen in acute pancreatitis.

The colon cut-off sign describes gaseous distension seen in the proximal colon associated with the narrowing of the splenic flexure. Though originally described in abdominal radiographs, this sign has also been demonstrated in contrast enema and computed tomography.

This appearance results from an inflammatory process extending from the pancreas into the phrenico-colic ligament via the transverse mesocolon. This causes functional spasm of the splenic flexure, resulting in the colon cut-off sign.

Other options:

Option A: Sentinel loop sign refers to the generalized or localized ileus of the intestine adjacent to the pancreas. A sentinel loop refers to a short segment of adynamic ileus adjacent to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. It is seen in acute pancreatitis.

Option C: Renal halo sign is produced by the apparent enhancement of the perirenal fat by an adjacent retroperitoneal exudate in the pararenal space. It is seen in acute pancreatitis.

Option D: Obliteration of the psoas shadow on imaging often indicates retroperitoneal pathology, such as infection, haemorrhage, or malignancy. It can suggest psoas abscess or inflammation in adjacent structures.

Related Pearl: X-Ray Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

Radiographic findings of acute pancreatitis are non-specific.

The sentinel loop is seen in an X-ray. It is a focal area of adynamic ileus close to an intra-abdominal inflammatory process. A sentinel loop in the upper abdomen indicates pancreatitis.

The sentinel loop sign may aid in localizing the source of inflammation. For example, a sentinel loop in the upper abdomen may indicate pancreatitis, while one in the right lower quadrant may be due to appendicitis.

Colon cut-off sign: Functional spasm at the splenic flexure due to the extension of inflammation to phrenicocolic ligament via transverse mesocolon.

 Renal halo sign: Edema around the kidney due to the involvement of paranephric fat resulting in:

  • Obliteration of psoas shadow
  • Localised ground-glass appearance

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of coronary artery disease presented with complaints of recurrent postprandial abdominal pain associated with vomiting and diarrhea. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness or rigidity. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Postprandial abdominal pain in the background of CAD is suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia(CMI). The most common cause of chronic mesenteric ischemia is atherosclerotic disease.

The three classic symptoms pathognomonic of CMI are:

  • Postprandial pain (crampy periumbilical abdominal pain within 30 minutes of meals)
  • Food fear (foods that precipitate symptoms are avoided by the patient and unintentional weight loss can result)
  • Significant weight loss

CT angiogram demonstrates both the arterial lesion and the patterns of collateral blood flow.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) and stenting have gained acceptance as the first line of therapy for mesenteric ischemia. 

Nutcracker syndrome refers to compression of the left renal vein, most commonly between the aorta and the superior mesenteric artery, with impaired blood outflow often accompanied by distention of the distal portion of the vein. Most commonly presents with hematuria, flank pain, and varicoceles. 

CT image of nutcracker syndrome showing compression of the LRV between the aorta and the SMA:

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with postcoital bleeding. She was diagnosed as a case of carcinoma cervix stage IB after evaluation. Treatment of choice in this patient is____
questions.solution:
Type 3 hysterectomy/Radical hysterectomy, pelvic lymphadenectomy, para aortic lymph node evaluation – is the treatment of choice in Stage 1 B.

Stage IB lesions are defined as those extending past the limits of microinvasion yet still confined to the cervix. T stage is subcategorized either as IB1 if tumors measure<2cm  or as IB2 if they measure 2cm to <4cm.

 

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

 Modified Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: You are prescribing estrogen therapy for a woman with hot flushes. What is the minimum number of days in a month during which you should combine it with progesterone?
questions.solution:
A minimum of 12 days (in a month) of progesterone must be added to estrogen therapy. This reduces the risk of endometrial cancer to 2%. 

The risk of cancer with estrogen therapy is dose and duration-dependent. Combined estrogen and progesterone provides better protection against endometrial cancer. 

Tibolone is a safe drug and does not cause endometrial hyperplasia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with pre-eclampsia is started on prophylactic MgSO4 in view of signs of impending eclampsia. An hour later, examination reveals RR - 16 breaths/minute and absent patellar reflexes. What is her plasma concentration of MgSO4 most likely to be?
questions.solution:
Patellar reflexes disappear when plasma magnesium concentration reaches 10 mEq/L. As there is no respiratory depression, the plasma concentration is likely to be 10-12 mEq/L.

The disappearance of the patellar reflex is the first sign of impending magnesium toxicity. MgSO4 is prophylactically used in impending eclampsia, severe pre-eclampsia, and HELLP syndrome.

Signs of magnesium toxicity Plasma concentrations of magnesium (mEq/L)
Loss of patellar reflex 10–12
Respiratory depression 12-13 
Cardiac arrest >30

questions.text: A neonate is being evaluated for the finding shown in the image. The mother's prenatal history is significant for viral exanthem in early pregnancy.  On examination, a grade 3 murmur is heard on auscultation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's murmur?
questions.solution:
The image shows a bilateral cataract, which along with the antenatal history of viral exanthem is suggestive of congenital rubella syndrome. Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is the most common congenital heart disease associated with rubella, followed by pulmonary artery stenosis (PS).

Frequency of heart disease in congenital rubella: PDA > PS > VSD > ASD.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presented with the following findings. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image shows an upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage characteristically seen in Sprengel deformity.

Sprengel deformity is a congenital upward elevation of the scapula. It is due to the failure of the scapula to descend completely in embryonic life.

The affected scapula is smaller, shaped differently, abnormally high, and somewhat prominent. Shoulder movements are usually painless. Abduction and elevation of shoulders may be limited due to fixation of the scapula.

The Cavendish classification is used to grade the severity of Sprengel deformity. 

If the deformity is mild, no treatment is required. In severe deformity, surgery may be indicated. These procedures include:

  • Green procedure
  • Woodward procedure
  • Mears procedure

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was evaluated for memory problems. Her husband first noticed the issue about  4 or 5 years back but attributed the symptoms to old age. Gradually her forgetfulness worsened and began to interfere with her daily activities such as housekeeping. A month ago, she got lost while returning from the church which she had been visiting regularly for the past 30 years. No personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances were observed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of insidious loss of episodic memory followed by slowly progressive dementia is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease. This primarily involves the neurodegeneration of the cholinergic system.

Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia, followed by vascular dementia and Lewy body dementia.

Option B: Absence of prior cerebrovascular accident history or focal neurological deficits rules out vascular dementia.          

Option C: Absence of gait disturbance, rigidity (Parkinsonism) rules out dementia with Lewy bodies. 

Option D: Absence of early personality changes rules out Pick's disease.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibody against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - aducanumab

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male in kidney failure with a serum creatinine of 2.1 mg/dl is scheduled for surgery. Which of the following muscle relaxants can be used?
  1. Succinylcholine
  2. Atracurium
  3. D-tubocurarine
  4. Cis-atracurium
  5. Pancuronium
questions.solution:
Succinylcholine, atracurium and cis-atracurium can be used in this patient who has a renal failure with elevated serum creatinine(normal value- 0.8–1.3 mg/dL in men and 0.6–1 mg/dL in women).

Succinylcholine can be safely administered to patients with diminished or absent kidney function provided serum potassium levels are normal. If the serum potassium is increased, then a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant like atracurium or cisatracurium which is non-dependent on renal excretion is to be used. Atracurium or cisatracurium undergo Hofmann elimination which is non-enzymatic spontaneous degradation.

Pancuronium is almost entirely dependent on the kidney for excretion (60–90%). Pancuronium has a prolonged elimination half-life in renal failure patients and thus should be used very cautiously.

40-60% of d-tubocurarine is excreted via the kidney and so prolonged effects are seen with renal insufficiency

 

Related Pearl: Anaesthetic drugs in patients with reduced renal function

Inhaled anaesthetics:

  • Safe- halothane, isoflurane, desflurane
  • Unsafe- methoxyflurane, enflurane, and sevoflurane

 Intravenous anaesthetics:

  • Safe- Propofol, Ultrashort acting barbiturates like thiopental, methohexital
  • Unsafe- Benzodiazepines such as diazepam

 Opioids:

  • Safe- Remifentanil> Fentanyl > Alfentanil > Sufentanil
  • Unsafe:
    • Morphine (metabolized to morphine 3/6 glucuronide which is excreted through the kidney)
    • Meperidine (metabolite normeperidine is excreted through the kidney)
    • Hydromorphone (metabolite H-3-glucuronide accumulate in renal failure patients)

 Muscle relaxants:

  • Safe- Atracurium, Cisatracurium
  • Unsafe- Rocuronium, Mivacurium

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with the following lesion. DNA Analysis from tissue samples for T-cell receptor analysis showed clonal rearrangements of the T-cell receptor genes. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features along with the characteristic investigation of T-cell receptor analysis showing clonal rearrangement of the T-cell receptor(TCR) is diagnostic of Mycosis fungoides.

  • Mycosis fungoides is characterized by polymorphic patches and plaques usually involving limb/girdle sites, the breast and especially the buttock area.
  • It is characterized by subtle, fine, scaly and often slightly atrophic (wrinkled) erythematous patches.

T‐cell receptor gene analysis consists of the analysis of DNA from tissue samples for the detection of clonal rearrangements of the TCR genes as a marker of a monoclonal T‐cell population. T‐cell clones can be detected in a proportion (70% overall) of skin biopsies from patients with early‐stage disease and are almost invariable in patients with later stages of the disease.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The X-ray shows left-sided pneumothorax with the partial collapse of the left lung. Best X-ray view to diagnose pneumothorax is PA view in full expiration.

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Visible visceral pleural edge is seen as a very thin, sharp white line
  • No lung markings are seen peripheral to this line
  • The peripheral space is radiolucent compared to the adjacent lung.
  • The lung may completely collapse.
  • The mediastinum should not shift away from the pneumothorax unless a tension pneumothorax is present.
  • Subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum may also be present.
  • The deep sulcus sign on a supine chest radiograph is an indication of a pneumothorax. In a supine film (common in the ICU), it may be the only indication of a pneumothorax because air collects anteriorly and basally, within the nondependent portions of the pleural space, as opposed to the apex when the patient is upright. The costophrenic angle is abnormally deepened when the pleural air collects laterally, producing the deep sulcus sign.

AP view plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax in a patient with bilateral pneumonia. There is an increase of transradiancy at the left lung base and the costophrenic sulcus laterally is more pronounced (‘deep sulcus sign’).

questions.text: A patient with carcinoma endometrium is treated with pelvic external beam irradiation. Which of the following organs is likely to be affected the most?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the ovary is most likely to be affected as it is the most radiosensitive organ. 

Radiosensitivity of pelvic organs is as follows: ovary>rectum>bladder>vagina. Radiation tolerance dose for ovary is 2-3 Gy whereas vagina 90 Gy. Hence, among the given options, the vagina is the most radioresistant organ.

The radiation dose necessary to induce ovarian failure is age-dependent. A single dose of 3-4 Gray can induce amenorrhea in almost all women >40 yrs of age. In young women, oogenesis is much less sensitive to radiation as compared to the elderly. 

Radiosensitivity of various tissues is summed up in the table given below: 

  Most radiosensitive Least radiosensitive
Tissue Bone marrow, Gonads Nervous tissue, Muscle fibers
Blood cells Lymphocytes Platelets
Stages of cell cycle G2M interphase S phase
Cell types Rapidly dividing Quiescent
Ocular structure Lens Sclera
Layer of retina Rods Ganglion cell layer

The skin is most commonly affected due to radiation. Stratum basalis is the layer of the skin most affected.
